column4: How do I figure out if a machine is Ubuntu Server or Desktop?
2.6.15-52-686, and what does that tell me?

They're not exactly different.  You can use uname like deany said to determine the kernel, but that won't tell you much anyway (you can have either kernel on either).  You can also check to see if X is installed
That means you're running Dapper, and it's likely a desktop machine.
X is installed, but I may have installed it on top of a server edittion  :)_
Indeed.  There isn't really a hard fast way to tell, because they're not different.
alternate can also be server and desktop, right?
It can install a desktop box with a GUI, or a CLI-only box, yes.  But it's not the same as the "server" flavor, which has a separate kernel

But the alternate CD has the most packages on it, and it'll result in you needing to download fewer from the internet during install.  Of course, you also will have updates after you upgrade, so if you're just using a CD to save on bandwidth, I say just go with the straight internet upgrade.
I'm just using a CD to save on traffic , and I have ubuntu-8.04-desktop-i386.iso and ubuntu-8.04-server-i386.iso
so whatever I use it shouldn't hurt anything, just affect the amount of stuff it downloads?

You need the alternate CD.  Desktop can't be used to upgrade.  However, consider this:  You're going to download the 700MB alternate CD to save on about 500MB worth of packages (which you'll then need to upgrade anyway, since 8.04.2 was released a few weeks ago)
Actually, you only have 8.04, so those packages are even older.  I honestly would just say do a straight upgrade from the internet.  Those packages are almost a year old
It *may* work, but hasn't been tested/verified to work.  Dapper-updates + full up-to-date ensures a known configuration pre-upgrade
mmm, yes, the do-* cli thing
